displayed_text: Patient: Yeah. I - Doctor: Well, I mean, I don’t know. I can find out from the group at Cornell which sounds like at least would be- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Within striking distance for you from, from the east coast. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: How quickly? If you’re eligible, how quickly you could uh- Patient: Sure. Sure. Doctor: You could go on before you uh, I think their trial is a, so it’s called a phase one trial. So what does that mean? So phase one traditionally was uh a dose-finding trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it determines how toxic things were. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: So with drugs what will often happen is a patient on a phase one where you came at an early stage you’d get a very low dose, probably too low to have toxicity but too low to be effective. And when you get to the high dose, it might be plenty to be effective but toxic, so you’d always sort of be Goldilocks at the end. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Huh? Doctor: Last time, what happened? Did they give you the medicine? Patient: No, I, I, I just, the last one you gave me is the one that I lost. But I picked up the one that you gave me before then. Doctor: Before? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So, you picked it up on August thirtieth? Patient: The, no, the, I think Doctor: The last medication? Patient: No, I think the fifth. I think the fifth. Doctor: The fifth of September. Patient: Yeah, the fifth. Doctor: Okay. So, I’m going to then, uh, give you one with this date, with the end of September date. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Um. Doctor: So that’s what D___ and I will work on. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. So I’ll to go - Doctor: Well then let me; I think she’s out here but I know she will have been in touch with you, but I think she wanted me to clear you today to say hey, that she’s still a candidate because his blood tests have improved and acts with – PSA isn’t bad. Okay. Uh are there questions that you guys have? So we talked about diet; we talked about Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But right now they’re going to spend a little bit more time seeing if the trial makes sense for you – Patient: Right. Doctor: and go through that. Family Member: So tomorrow at ten o’clock even if he has, he’s going to see the urologist, should we send you or will you be in touch with them or how? Doctor: We’ve been getting the notes from whoever you see. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Oh okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Doctor: It’s like a pattern with you! Doctor: No, I was here for the appointment they gave you, though. Patient: I got a call from S____, and I called her right back and I said, “I thought you guys told me to come here later?” And, she said, “No, we want you to come here.” And so, I’m here today. But, no, I could’ve, I was telling, somebody left a voice message… Doctor: Okay. Patient: And said that you have to change to this date. And, I said, “Okay.” Doctor: Okay. Alright. This is what’s going on. Your PSA has been going up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Remember that? Patient: Right. Doctor: And we stopped the Casodex, correct? Patient: Right. Doctor: You’ve been off of it. Patient: Yes. Just Lupron

Patient: Right. Okay. Yeah sounds good. Doctor: You’ll get your orders to get your blood work, the Aximun scan maybe at our baby site, you know. Patient: Okay Doctor: So, we'll get into a radiology schedule- Patient: All right. Doctor: -uh as we need it, if I find more out by the end of the week, but how to get it scheduled. I’ll let you know. Patient: Okay, that sounds good. And I'll get up on MyChart. Healthcare Professional: This is yours. And it was LabCorps, right? Patient: Yeah. Healthcare Professional: This is yours. And here is- Patient: The summary. Healthcare Professional: The summary. And it should have the MyChart. Yes. Your activation code is down there.

Family Member: Can’t be sure? Doctor: Well, let me explore, so I’ve got a couple of threads I’ve got to explore a little more. Patient: Thank you. I appreciate that. Doctor: So let’s uh- Patient: So we’re off the trial now? Doctor: Yeah. We’re off the trial. We’ll probably just want to see a PSA in another month off the testosterone. That may be complicated because you may, because we’re working to go somewhere else so, it may not be that useful for us because it’s not like you’re going to be on- Healthcare Professional: Is it thirty days as before? In those terms I don’t know- Doctor: We’ll, we’ll see. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Perfect. Doctor: And so I will be in touch by the end of the week to tell you what I’ve, what I’ve learned. Okay? Patient: Alright. Thank you. Doctor: So just for, for now, Germany, I get what they want, the test results, uh, I’ll see what the policy says about you know just paying for, for the drugs. Okay? Patient: Yeah.

Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: I don’t know either. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They just said it was inadequate. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we don’t have any results about are there gene studies that you could go on. Uhm, so the ARV7 positive means that you know your cancer is pretty smart and knows how to grow despite testosterone being low, despite being on drugs like the Zytiga or the Xtandi, and that really you know as I said last time, at some point we have to decide when your cancer is worse. I tend not to rely on PSA. Patient: Mm. Doctor: It really is are there new things about you that are going in the wrong direction and yet after radiation, it seems like things are in a better direction at least in the last month in terms of your pain. Patient: Oh yes, absolutely. Doctor: We’ve got a CAT scan that I don’t have access to, but sort of what does that show? And with you know new belly films you know to sort of say what’s going on in your liver, you know so Dr. G___ and I can talk about that, sort of when, what images we need, to say okay his PSA is higher and on scan we see more cancer. And you know some of what we’re really talking about is what do we do if we tell you that. Does that bring up questions? Patient: In other words where do we go from here? Doctor: What is your understanding or what Dr. G__ talked about. Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So what I’m going to suggest is that we change to a different kind of chemotherapy. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because the advantage is that you know this mass that is resistant to the current chemotherapy will hopefully… Patient: Do you think that, you think that… Doctor: Respond. Patient: Okay. Nah you can keep Dr. V____. Doctor: Well hopefully it will respond to the second one, the one that we use if people are resistant to this particular chemo that you’re on. Patient: What, what is this one gonna be? Doctor: What is what? Patient: This chemo, what you, what you gonna suggest? Doctor: So this is a medication called Cabazitaxel. I’ll give you information and the name and everything. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Well, one thing, I said the wrong side. It’s not the right side. It’s the left side. Doctor: Uh-huh. Patient: But I’m starting to think I . I wouldn’t even do that. Doctor: So it got a little worse from when you saw me but actually it hasn’t gotten worse in the last week or so? Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Okay. Okay. So there’s only one medicine on here that I’m looking at. Huh, do you take acyclovir? Did they put you on that? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Huh, so are you finished with that? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And then so you’re still taking the abiraterone four pills a day? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, the acyclovir is the one that they’ve asked you to take for ten days, probably for this? Huh, the Dulcolax to help for constipation? The Natural Tears now for your eye? The iron pill one, huh, three times a day? Patient: Yep. Well.

Patient: Right. Doctor: When you walk, how can you walk otherwise? Patient: Exactly. Doctor: And, you know, so that is a critical area that we may need to Patient: Okay. Doctor: do radiation to sort of help control it while we are planning for all of this other stuff. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, that’s our plan. So, going forward, you’re going to have to see me much more frequently than before. Patient: That’s fine. I like you. I would not mind seeing you more frequently. Doctor: Thank goodness.

Family Member 1: At the hospital. Doctor: You can get food gloves if you want, you know? Family Member 1: Yeah we have hospital gloves. Family Member 2: And then put them in a bag. Doctor: That's it. Patient: Yeah nothing complicated. Doctor: Nothing complicated. Family Member 1: Flush twice. Doctor: Nothing complicated. Family Member 2: He’s wiping the toilet, but he’s also wiping the sink with a separate wipe. Doctor: He’s wiping the toilet. So kind of like where you're at, just swipe around it and then when everything blows up, boom in here. Good. Good. Family Member 1: And so when he washes his hands?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The PSA tells me it’s either this time or three months from now that we’re likely to see a change. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But that’s what we’ve learned about Enzalutamide; don’t give up the ship until it’s clearly different. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Okay? Because these drugs could be providing a dampening effect Patient: Yeah, I know that. Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: So. Um. You know, my sense is that it is research because we’ve got a new drug added to it. You know, looking forward to having the conversation about what options might be still important. Um. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um. Um. (Pause5sec) Patient: So, why don’t we try to, to, to have the blood taken and, and, see if, if what that brings back, but maybe a a - in lieu of that possibly being negative, um, look at the other clinical trial. Doctor: So, I’ll go print out, uh, do you want me to just not print out the chemo one?

Patient: Oh, yeah. I’ll give you a heads up. You don’t have to worry about it. Patient: You don’t have to fix all that. That ain’t our best. Family Member: Who makes the appointment for it? Doctor: You got to do it. So when you walk out, right where you checked in, they will give you the times that’s convenient to both of you. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: They will scan and go when you’re done. Patient: We can’t go in the waiting room. We’ve still got a video to shoot. Doctor: Yeah. We’ve got a video to shoot. Yeah. (Laughter) Doctor: Oh, they’re ready for you, for your next take. I’ll take my paper now. Patient: I’ll see you later.

Patient: Yeah, yeah, at the same time, so Doctor: Yeah so hopefully that will put money in the bank and back in two days for your calcium and doing all the right thigns to keep your bones strong. Patient: Yeah Doctor: Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Great I’ll let you head out and uh we’ll get these things off Patient: Happy New Year! Doctor: Yeah, Happy New Year to you as well.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s folks who have like not so much hair at this age who just easily lose it. You have a lot of hair. Patient: Yes. When I was on the uh Cometriq. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: It started a little thinning but it was turning white. Doctor: Yeah. Um hum. Healthcare Professional: Um hum. Patient: And then we adjusted the dose and it started coming. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: I had to straighten this way.
